case_title: SHREE JANKKI SOLVENT EXTRACTIONS LTD. and 2 others vs DEPUTY DIRECTOR OF INCOME-TAX (INVESTIGATION) and others
reference_no_or_id: Civil Miscellaneous/Writ Petitions Nos.189, 190 and 192 of 1995
case_number: Civil Miscellaneous/Writ Petitions Nos.189, 190 and 192 of 1995
complaint_summary: The appellants challenged the requisition order issued under Section 132-A(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, arguing that the conditions for invoking the section were not satisfied.
investigation_summary: The requisitioning authority failed to record satisfaction or belief that the documents would not be produced if summons were issued, rendering the order invalid.

judgment_summary.order_quashed: Order of requisition dated January 23, 1995, quashed.
judgment_summary.documents_returned: Documents to be returned to trade tax authorities.
judgment_summary.liberty_to_act: Respondents may take steps in accordance with law for assessment year 1993-94.

Decision_or_verdict: Writ petition allowed; requisition order quashed.
legal_arguments: Section 132-A(1)(b) requires satisfaction of both conditions: documents must be relevant to a pending proceeding, and there must be belief that the documents will not be produced.
Explanation 2 of Section 132 does not apply to Section 132-A(1)(b) as argued by the defense.
Prosecution argued that Explanation 2 applies to all subsections of Section 132, including Section 132-A(1)(b).
No finding of satisfaction that documents would not be produced if summons issued.
citations: ITO v. Madnani Engineering Works Ltd. (1979) 118 ITR 1 (SC)
key_issues: Validity of requisition order under Section 132-A(1)(b)

legal_terms.Requisition: A formal demand for documents or evidence.
legal_terms.Pending Proceeding: A legal process that is currently ongoing.

words_and_phrases.Legislation by Reference: Adopting provisions of another statute by reference.
words_and_phrases.Nullity: A legal act that is invalid and has no effect.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the validity of a requisition order under Section 132-A(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act, 1961. The court found that the requisitioning authority failed to record satisfaction or belief that the documents would not be produced if summons were issued, rendering the order invalid. The writ petition was allowed, and the order was quashed.
